snippet.textDisplay:
I'm going to make a request, because I (and probably many others) would love to hear your thoughts on Bear McCreary's God of War.

On topic: I was never impressed with Avatar's worldbuilding. I refuse to take a film that shamelessly recycles iconic sound effects from Jurassic Park and place that alongside The Lord of the Rings in terms of conlangs or other worldbuilding elements. For every little out-of-the-ordinary detail, there's Jake's avatar being saved from plummeting to his death by conveniently placed giant banana leaves. To say nothing of the fact Cameron hired a bunch of experts, whereas Tolkien did the work himself.

snippet.textDisplay: Oh, god... I'm so upset... Like, it really feels like a punch in the gut when you learn about all the things Horner (may he rest in peace) and Bryant did to make the soundtrack sound different and it would have been mesmerizing but all of it got dismissed because "it sounded weird"? ... I'm sorry but that sounds so offensive. They wanted to make something unique, that sounded like the entire world symphony and got rejected for the sake of western sounds because, somehow , it sounds more appealing to the audience's ears. Ugh, it's so tiring to have Hollywood stereotyping other cultures over and over and over again, with costumes, dances, behavior, skin color, and what brought us to this video, music. In the end, it's like "let's bring all of these stereotypical elements of cultures (that are not our own) because they are exotic and will look good" but they don't have any meaning, they just look and sound like they are from those cultures or like you said, is what western audiences think nonwestern music sounds like.

snippet.textDisplay: Nope. Cameron did what he was there for perfectly. The argument of this video is an example of a huge argument that goes on all the time between the 'artists' in society and the 'merchants' in the society. If you leave it to the artists, they will create many amazing, unusual, and artistically correct things. And, they will very often financially fail, be unsuccessful, misunderstood, under-appreciated, etc. This is what you see with individual solo artists all the time and that's fine for them if they want to make that sacrifice on principle. But when you're spending hundred of millions of dollars on a project involving hundreds of people - it needs to be financially successful, and that means it needs to connect with a broad swathe of people. It does not need to be 'correct' or authentic or artistically sound if that endangers acceptance by the masses. It needs to be appealing to its targeting audience. Marketing is the part of this you're ignoring. For a major film, if the audience doesn't "feel" the music correctly - given their experience and expectations - it could mean the difference between everyone getting paid and financial ruin. Never leave a financial product in the hands of an unrestrained artist. Sorry, but that's just how the world works.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thing is you cant have a film with a budget north of $200 million and expect artistic integrity and not checkbox unchallenging drivel made for joe focus group.

These films are not made to show us something new, its primary aim is always profit. There is no sincere creative yearning behind this or any other mega budget film with the exception of some pixar stuff. But there you could argue that profits are easier to achieve with films marketed to children with a more universal appeal.

There are appealing elements of these films but the term 'turn your brain off' can consistently be used to describe or even dismiss them. That phrase is a studio corporate hack's best friend

snippet.textDisplay:
It's very disappointing to learn what we missed out on in this. I'm not sure how fair the comparison with colonization and exploitation (I take it this was the implicit irony) is, though, since nothing was being stolen from Bryant - perhaps what I fear in this is conflating disinterest in scholarship about other cultures with disrespect for other cultures.

The scholarly ambition in question wasn't defending anybody's culture, nor ultimately the source of Avatar's legitimacy, it was a (by the sounds of it) very impressive creative project supported by a movie aimed at Western audiences that wanted that level of creativity in the service of a story they would want to watch and understand. When that creativity ran up against the larger goal - and if James Cameron didn't find it accessible, I sort of suspect at least a portion of his audience wouldn't have either - then its being cut was a betrayal of the original billing, but also probably in the interests of everyone involved except the people who were given carte blanche to do all of it in the first place. I'm sure that if some aspect of Pandoran biology didn't work with what JC had already imagined, e.g. something as big as a horse probably not being able to live off of ants, he would have ignored that too, and the biologists he consulted would have felt frustrated and useless. But I think it's fair to say that this is what happens when a bunch of people who love specific areas of study are individually told to be as creative and intentionally exotic as they can, then bring it all together, and then have it incorporated into the master plan of a non-expert who has probably imagined a lot of it already on the basis of their own aesthetic sensibility - it sounds really good, at first, but the person who originally came up with it has by design not really thought it through, so toes will be stepped on, and toes will be crushed. A huge disappointment to everyone nerding out over it in the first place but also not so much exploitation as just poor long-term planning.

Yes, the score ultimately just plays into Western ideas of foreignness, but the same goes for the movie as a whole, both as it was and as it wanted to be - it is not a representation of any real culture with dignity on the line, but a Western imagination of an encounter with something foreign to itself. Indeed, that remains true even when the Westerner is a scholar of things foreign to Westerners. And to be honest, I think that such a work is just fine - having things be foreign to you is part of living, and it is fair to want to represent that experience in a way accessible to yourself and others. It may even be better not to incorporate bits of others' cultures into that image of foreignness.

Anyway, that's my two and a half cents. Thanks for the video, I did enjoy it and find it informative and it gave me something to think about.

snippet.textDisplay:
i understand that a lot of people are frustrated with the movie for various reason, i've always loved it and found it efficient in its storytelling.


it's disheartening to hear you shit on it here, because it's derivative. i don't think a story being derivative makes it, you know, not worth telling. just because something is a stand-in for a horse or a rhino, doesn't make it crap per se, i think. it's sort of like criticising why the na'vi are bipedal, i mean, they are supposed to be relatable on some level, so yeah it would be more alien to make them more alien but in the end, the movie was supposed to sell to as many people possible, so you can't really alienate the audience by making them, whatever, eat with their anuses or something.


it just annoys me to feel that this is mostly nitpicking, movie isn't awesome enough because it's too much like things we already know. well, newsflash, most stories are endlessly retold, and yet we watch them and read them at all times.

Other than visuals and the tech behind it it was about the most generic blockbuster movie I’ve ever seen seeming to be lacking any thought other than “pokahantus did well let’s do that but with blue aliens and a pretty planet and the invaders will be humans with the helicopters from Halo 3”
Nothing felt organial at all just like a bunch of the greatest hits so to speak glued together and propped up again by the visuals, and don’t even get me started on how exhaustingly dumb and generic the characters are and how annoying the way they talk is like “wait this might get to nerdy, let’s make them cuss a lot and talk like ThE KiDs Do ThEsE dAyS” like shut up your trying so hard it feels like it was written by a middle schooler,
Just make your characters talk and act like people!

As for them the artists deserve so much credit, I really don’t like anything about this movie other than how it looks and yet I’ve watched it multiple times since just to see it and I’m not easily swayed by visuals alone, but it’s just so pretty and that makes me want it to be good for it to be a movie that simply explores this plannet and all, but then characters get in the way cuz they’re all bad and you realize it’s a beautiful backdrop the hard work of very talented masters of their work who deserved better than to have their work shat on by the subpar story accompanying it and characters cringy dialogue taking you completely out of the movie

snippet.textDisplay: Something rubbed me the wrong way about this movie from the first time I saw it. In fact, a number of things did. Okay, I actually kinda hated the movie, and I've never come to like it over time. Now, I'm not saying that I was clued into the musical issues at all, but I find this look into the way the music was created to be very indicative of the kinds of things that I didn't like about the movie, and the comparison of the colonialistic approach to the "nonwestern" music to the way that the villains acted is quite spot on. I will definitely be sharing this with some of my friends.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly, I had no idea that there was such a sad history to the music of this movie. I admit, of all things I remember from this movie, the music is not one of them and for good reason. It's generic and forgettable. Hearing all that you shared, in a way I'm surprised, but also it feels fitting with the final product of the movie. Despite the fact that James Cameron wanted this movie to be an immersive experience, to flesh out the world and the environment, it feels very shallow. I don't hate Avatar, I think it's an okay-ish movie, but there are problems that can't be ignored. The story itself is bare bones, and comparing it to Dances with Wolves, Ferngully, The Lorax, is not an exaggeration. The only thing Avatar was good for, the only thing that had the most effort and money put into it, was the visual effects. What kind of music would the Navi make? Who cares. What kind of language do they speak? Eh, we'll get someone on it. Why are the humans so hellbent on getting the Navi to move? Some rock called "Unobtainium". What does it do? Why is it all conveniently concentrated under the big tree? Why are you asking perfectly logical questions when you can look at the world they made out of CGI? James only cared about the look of the Navi, the look of the mining equipment, the giant mechs the humans piloted, the plants, trees, and animals on the planet, and that's it, and that's why I don't look forward to the sequel. Odds are, it'll be the same thing. Make the world look pretty, but hollow at its core.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m so disappointed in this video. I ABSOLUTELY LOVED AVATAR AND EVERYTHING ABOUT IT. The ride and park is one of the most amazing things in the world and I’ve watched that film probably over 100 times and never get tired of it. I loved the soundtrack so much and as someone in the industry, your lack of understanding of how this process is EXACTLY how every process for every film works, really bothers me. This woman was paid to present her ideas and research. That’s how every film is made. You pay for people to bring their expertise to the project and then you use that as a foundational jumping off point for your film. The fact that you’re shitting on this film for giving her a job in the first place is dumb. Shitting on the film for exposing people to all of this incredible world building is dumb. Acting like it wasn’t the most successful film in history and isn’t beloved (it is despite the noise on the internet) is dumb. Avengers isn’t a solo film. If it was, it would’ve made maybe $400million tops. The reason it broke the record (which by the way, required a re-release), is because it is the FINAL SEQUEL IN A 22 FILM SERIES. The culmination of a series of films that took place over more than a literal decade. I LOVE the MCU, but disrespecting that James Cameron built a universe that was so dense and impacted so many aspects of our industry that an ORIGINAL FILM THAT WAS NOBODY ELSES IDEA became the biggest film in history (and still is without including THE SEQUEL OF ALL SEQUELS) is ridiculous. Shitting on the people that spent countless hours, days, weeks, and months of work to create this dense world is not cool. You didn’t even bother to THANK JAMES CAMERON FOR MAKING A FILM FOR YOU TO SHIT ON FOR YOUR CHANNEL. This is the most disrespectful bullshit in the world because YOU ARE NOT STUPID. I could look over all of this if you were an idiot. If you were some stupid internet troll I would be able to just move on. But you’re clearly smart and know what you’re talking about when it comes to music, which makes it so frustrating that you would just shit on so many peoples hard work and efforts, which were qualified by becoming the most successful film project in history. I don’t expect you to care about anything I’m saying but I expect more from people like you, because your attitude towards this film is literally beneath you. You’re better than this.

snippet.textDisplay: Something to remember: not all "ethnic" music is non-western. A lot of the ethnic samples that you mentioned Bryant bringing to the table were from European ethnic groups, like Saami yoiking or Celtic laments. In fact, the Lament at the Tree of Souls sounds exactly like Gaelic Psalm singing, which is still practiced in Gaelic speaking areas of Scotland.

snippet.textDisplay: Just to preface, I don’t really care for this movie, but... I think this critique is a like bit over the top, just for the sake that, while yes the score is shit for the most part. The score seems to be complimentary to the vision being told visually. If James Cameron thought that something more “alien” wouldn’t compliment the rest of the piece, he has the duty to change it to something that is more compatible. Do I think it was pretty redundant of him to put money and time into creating music that he didn’t end up using, yes. But I think what goes to show here is when it comes to making this kind of film a good score vs a bad score wouldn’t be enough to push this movie out of the ditch it is already in.

snippet.textDisplay:
Imagine you tell someone to make you "Alien Art", so they come up with these extremely rare colors that Western art just doesn't use, combine them in schemes and patterns found in like 3 long forgotten ancient cultures and create an artwork that portrays not only a scenery we've never seen before but also an emotion we can't feel with methods that haven't been used in centuries, even less so by Europeans and Americans.
And then they present this artwork to you and you just say "Nah, that's too abstract. People won't get that. How about you just paint a cherry blossom tree by a lake but using these colors? But don't forget to use the colors in what I perceive as normal and natural combinations and contrasts so it's not too jarring for my Western eyes."

That's what happened here. They created a language, sounds, instruments, a whole new scale for their music - and then James Cameron was like "that's too alien for my movie about aliens. I can't identify with these sounds. Make it sound more recognizable to my Western ears.".

They delivered. They delivered so good. Too good. They delivered to a point where the music actually became alien to our ears. And James Cameron was afraid that people would not be able to identify with a music that they couldn't relate to anything they had heard before, so they forced them to ditch almost all of it and shove the rest of what they had created into a basic American-European shape of music.

Imagine how pissed Americans or English people would be if I, as a German, just wrote a nonsense poem using English words in a way that made the patterns sound German to me with just the sounds being non-German because they are English. Infuriating, right? And that's what came of it. Cameron used all these tools and sounds that were so alien and then just forced them into something resembling Western music and claimed it was alien just because the sounds were.
